content:
Drug: Methamphetamine | cid: 10836
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.
Erowid name: meth
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Effects

                    Text: 
                    This black mid-weight zip hoodie (80/20) has front pockets, an Erowid logo on front chest, and a spiral design on back.

Donate and receive yours!

Methamphetamines

Effects

by Erowid

DURATION #

Caution : Reactions and experiences may vary dramatically from person to person. [see below]

EFFECTS LIST #

POSITIVE

increased energy and alertness

decreased need for sleep

increased sociability

mild to extreme mood lift, euphoria

increased sexuality

NEUTRAL

excessive talking

decreased appetite, weight loss

sweating

NEGATIVE

disturbed sleep patterns

tightened jaw muscles, grinding teeth (trismus and bruxia)

loss of appetite (anorexia), leading to poor nutrition and weight loss with heavy use

visual & auditory hallucinations, hearing voices (from sleep deprivation)

reduced enjoyment of eating

loss of interest in sex, over time

itching, welts on skin

nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

dry mouth, leading to serious tooth decay with chronic use

excessive excitation, hyperactivity


                    Context: 
                    This excerpt provides detailed information about methamphetamines, including effects, duration, and associated risks, from Erowid's drug effects compilation. It is part of the Chemicals Vault section, offering users an understanding of methamphetamine's positive, neutral, and negative effects, crucial for research or harm reduction contexts.

content:
Drug: Methamphetamine | cid: 10836
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.
Erowid name: meth
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Effects

                    Text: 
                    loss of interest in sex, over time

itching, welts on skin

nausea, vomiting, diarrhea

dry mouth, leading to serious tooth decay with chronic use

excessive excitation, hyperactivity

shortness of breath

moodiness & irritability

anxiousness & nervousness

aggressiveness

panic, suspiciousness, and paranoia

involuntary body movements (uncontrollable movement and/or twitches of fingers, facial & body muscles, lip-smaking, tongue protrusion, grimacing, etc.)

ego inflation, false sense of confidence and power, ego-inflation

aggressive and violent behavior

severe depression, suicidal tendencies

Effects of Habitual Use

fatal kidney and lung disorders

possible brain damage

permanent psychological problems

lowered resistance to illnesses

liver damage

stroke

cardiovascular crises, chest pains, heart attacks

Damage to gums, teeth, and can lead to tooth loss

DESCRIPTION #

General Effects Notes


                    Context: 
                    This chunk details the negative physical and psychological effects associated with methamphetamine use, including symptoms like skin welts, nausea, hyperactivity, mood disturbances, and involuntary movements, as well as long-term health risks such as organ damage, brain injury, and dental decay. It is part of the broader effects section that describes methamphetamine's impact on users, vital for understanding its risks within the full webpage on drugs and substances.

metadata.title: Erowid Methamphetamines Vault : Effects
metadata.description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.

content:
Drug: Methamphetamine | cid: 10836
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.
Erowid name: meth
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Effects

                    Text: 
                    lowered resistance to illnesses

liver damage

stroke

cardiovascular crises, chest pains, heart attacks

Damage to gums, teeth, and can lead to tooth loss

DESCRIPTION #

General Effects Notes

When methamphetamine is first used, the effects can often feel somewhat more like MDMA (Ecstasy) than a simple stimulant including a sense of euphoria, openness, and intellectual expansion. There can be a mild psychedelic component as the new user feels they see the world a little differently. The sensation of 'mind-expansion' and openness quickly fade after the first few uses and physical and mental stimulation dominate the experiential effects.

Routes of Administration


                    Context: 
                    This excerpt details the health risks associated with methamphetamine use, including organ damage, stroke, cardiovascular issues, and dental deterioration. It also provides a description of initial effects and routes of administration, serving as a summary within the broader discussion of methamphetamine's physical and experiential effects in the full document.

metadata.title: Erowid Methamphetamines Vault : Effects
metadata.description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.

content:
Drug: Methamphetamine | cid: 10836
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.
Erowid name: meth
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Effects

                    Text: 
                    Routes of Administration

As with other psychoactives, different routes of administration have different profiles of effects. Oral methamphetamine ingestion tends to lack rushing, has less euphoric effects, and tends to cause far less of a feeling of wanting to do it again than the other methods. Smoking and injecting methamphetamine are associated with stronger, more euphoric effects and these are more associated with compulsive / addictive user patterns.

Addiction and Withdrawal

Users of large amount of amphetamines over a long period of time can develop an amphetamine psychosis, which is a mental disorder similar to paranoid schizophrenia. The psychosis is manifested by hallucinations, delusions, and paranoia. Bizarre, sometime violent, behavior is exhibited by those with amphetamine psychosis. Symptoms usually disappear within a few weeks after drug use stops.

Withdrawal Symptoms


                    Context: 
                    This section discusses the different routes of administration for methamphetamine and their effects, highlighting how usage methods influence euphoria and addiction potential. It also covers conditions like amphetamine psychosis resulting from long-term use, as well as withdrawal symptoms. These details are essential for understanding the behavioral and psychological risks associated with methamphetamine consumption.

metadata.title: Erowid Methamphetamines Vault : Effects
metadata.description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.

content:
Drug: Methamphetamine | cid: 10836
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.
Erowid name: meth
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Effects

                    Text: 
                    Withdrawal Symptoms

Amphetamines have the potential to produce tolerance, which means that increased amounts of the drug are needed to achieve the desired effects. Withdrawal symptoms can occur when use of amphetamines is stopped abruptly. Users may experience fatigue; long, disturbed periods of sleep; irritability; intense hunger, and moderate to severe depression. The length and severity of the depression is related to how much and how often amphetamines were used.

craving

exhaustion

depression

mental confusion

restlessness and insomnia

deep or disturbed sleep lasting up to 48 hours

extreme hunger

psychotic reaction

anxiety reactions

Treatment (from FADAA)


                    Context: 
                    This section details the withdrawal symptoms associated with amphetamine use, including fatigue, sleep disturbances, irritability, depression, and psychological effects, along with treatment options from FADAA. It provides crucial information on the physical and mental health consequences of stopping amphetamines, contextualizing the broader discussion of methamphetamine effects and addiction in the document.

metadata.title: Erowid Methamphetamines Vault : Effects
metadata.description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.

content:
Drug: Methamphetamine | cid: 10836
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.
Erowid name: meth
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Effects

                    Text: 
                    deep or disturbed sleep lasting up to 48 hours

extreme hunger

psychotic reaction

anxiety reactions

Treatment (from FADAA)

Medical treatments include the use of antidepressant agents such as imipramine, desipramine, amitriptyline, dosepin, trazodone, or fluoxetine (Prozac). These affect serotonin, the neurotransmitter in the brain that deals with both depression and drug craving. Sedatives such as Dalmane, chloral hydrate, Librium, phenobarbital, or even Valium are used, very carefully, on a short-term basis to treat anxiety or sleep disturbance problems. Antipsychotic medications such as Haldol, Thorazine, and others are also used to buffer the effects of unbalanced dopamine, the neurotransmitter that moderates paranoia and pleasurable sensation. In addition to treating the physical and psychological aspects of craving, treatment providers should stress group counseling and peer pressure for compulsive amphetamine users, as these forms of therapy work well for this population.


                    Context: 
                    This excerpt details common withdrawal symptoms from methamphetamine use, including sleep disturbances, increased hunger, and psychotic reactions, and describes medical treatment options such as antidepressants, sedatives, and antipsychotics. Its relevance lies in providing comprehensive information on managing severe withdrawal effects and guiding medical interventions for addiction treatment within the broader context of the document.

metadata.title: Erowid Methamphetamines Vault : Effects
metadata.description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.

content:
Drug: Methamphetamine | cid: 10836
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about the mental and physical effects of Methamphetamines.
Erowid name: meth
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: Effects

                    Text: 
                    Effects of use During Pregnancy

It is possible for babies of mothers who use amphetamines to be born with:

cardiac defects

cleft palate

birth defects

addiction and withdrawal

CAUTION & DISCLAIMER #

Erowid's effects information is a summary of data gathered from users, research, and other resources. This information is intended to describe the range of effects people report experiencing. Effects may vary dramatically from one person to another or one experience to another based on a variety of factors such as body chemistry, age, gender, physical health, dose, form of material, etc.

RELATED RESOURCES #

RELATED LINKS #
